results.notes:
A NJMA foray collection brought in to the ID table by unknown participants.

Amanita gracilissima Safonov, Kudzma & Tulloss nom. prov.
Common name: “the graceful Eastern North American ringless Lepidella (sensu Bas 1969)”
General profile: An amanita species, assignable to sect. Lepidella sensu Bas (1969) based on the gross morphology and DNA sequencing (nrLSU). The exannulate fruitbodies project a graceful and fragile appearance â reminiscent of grisettes and very unusual for the robust lepidella archetype â owing to their disproportionately long and slender stipes crowned by the small and thin-fleshed caps.
Description:
Caps: 3.3 & 4.3 cm in diameter at maturity, round and essentially planar, but appearing broadly umbonate due to a shallow circular depression at ~0.3R from the center; surface white to off-white, with diffuse rusty brown stains (mostly in the older specimen) of unknown origin, smooth, bald, somewhat glossy, slightly tacky, and non-virgate; margins non-striate and finely appendiculate; flesh 0.4 & 0.55 cm thick above the stipe, white to whitish, not staining upon exposure, and solid; universal veil present as a few small, removable and flat brown crusty warts on the disk, but otherwise observed as whitish, appressed wooly-felted deposits scattered around the cap periphery; gills 1.2 & 1.7 cm long, 0.35 & 0.6 cm broad, pale cream, with a floccose-powdery edge; short gills plentiful, of diverse length, mostly broadly attenuate, sometimes subattenuate with a rounded edge, and occasionally sub-truncate (in the smaller fruitbody).
Stipes: 9 & 13.5 cm long from apex to the tip of bulb, 0.8 and 0.9 cm wide at the juncture with caps, generally 0.6-0.75 cm wide between apex and bulb, subequal and narrowing in the upward direction, overall straight but noticeably bent in base, and round in cross-section; basal bulb up to 2.3 & 2.8 cm long and 0.85 & 0.95 mm wide, rather indistinct in intact fruitbodies, but looking carrot-shaped and slightly radicating when sectioned, narrowing to a pointy terminus, somewhat flattened in the older fruitbody; surface white, floccose-powdery in the upper Â¼ of length and minutely scruffy in the mid-section; flesh generally white in the smaller fruibody and pale cream to tannish (in the base area) in the older one due to being waterlogged, and solid; partial veil absent (likely evanescent and disappearing well before maturity); universal veil present as irregularly-shaped and unevenly distributed stacked bands of white, soft, scruffy and occasionally recurving scales above the bulb and on its upper section.
Odor: Stale, like a musty cellar, in the older fruitbody, more agreeable and sweetish in the younger one.
Taste: Not recorded (not tasted)
Spores: Mounted in Melzerâs and measured only in the profile (dorsi-ventral) view.
[40/1/1]: L x W = 7.0-9.8 Ã 5.6-7.7 Âµm, Lâ x Wâ = 8.4 Ã 6.8 Âµm; Q = (1.16-) 1.17-1.30 (-1.33), Qâ = 1.24;
White (as a spore print), smooth, hyaline and amyloid (staining was delayed!); symmetrical and balloon/pear-shaped in face view, slightly to mildly inequilateral in profile view due to a visible suprahilar depression, round in cross-section, and broadly ellipsoid.
DNA Sequencing Results:
Both nrITS and nrLSU were originally requested for this collection. Unfortunately, the former locus is hopelessly heterogeneous, which is a frequent occurrence in sect. Lepidella sensu Bas. The clean and contiguous nrLSU sequence is 1427 bps long. The read begins from the ~38th character from the start of the locus (ITS4 primer). There are no ambiguous characters.
A BLASTn of the first 945 characters (through to the LR5 primer) gave Amanita smithiana voucher RET 382-6 (HQ539740) as the âtop hitâ at 94.4% similarity. Thatâs pretty distant for this conserved locus. The attached annotated phylogram built from the carefully selected 52 BLASTn hits firmly places gracilissima into sect. Lepidella sensu Bas (1969). A clear phylogenetic separation from sections Validae and Phalloideae is demonstrated. The taxa not found in North America are highlighted in magenta; accessions of type material are highlighted in green.
As a side note, Bas’ sect. Lepidella was found to be polyphyletic in the recent multi-locus phylogenetic study of Amanita by Cui et al. (Fungal Diversity 2018, term 91: 5-230). In the new taxonomic scheme, the monophyly and infrageneric stability of Amanita are preserved. However, section Lepidella of subgenus Lepidella is reserved only for the extant saprotrophic taxa and is typified by A. vittadinnii. Because of this, the third subgenus, Amanitina, now accommodates the greater bulk of Bas’ lepidellas (in two new sections, Roanokenses and Strobiliformes), as well as all the taxa housed in the still legitimate sects. Amidella, Phalloideae, and Validae.

Growing on the underside of a hardwood log near Pinus strobus, Quercus sp., Carya sp., Fagus grandifolia and other hardwoods. Rhizomorphs present at the margins. All structures inamyloid. results.notes:
On shale in coastal scrub habitat near the ocean. The top layer of the shale actually had chunks of shell embedded in it (HCL+ presumably). The specimen is pretty scant, collected incidentally with Lecania.

Thallus chalky white, thin, continuous to somewhat rimose-areolate, K+Y barely, C-. Apothecia tiny, black, plane, with a raised rim. Epihymenium dark brown, POL-, without aeruginose pigments (ie: not likely Buellia maritima). Hymenium hyaline, hypothecium dark brown. Exciple thick and dark, K- (No violet).

Spores 1-septate, brown, about 11×5Âµm. (oh, and btw, micrometer sign shortcut is Alt230 on keyboard. Keep meaning to post that.)

results.notes:
On hard shale rock in coastal scrub near the ocean.

Thallus whitish and thin and rimose-areolate becoming thick, grey, angular areolate with deep fissures and a warty surface, K-. Apothecia brown to black, epruinose to weakly pruinose, with a raised rim when young, often irregularly shaped/flexuous/folded, to conglomerate and convex, always with a constricted base. Epihymenium dark brown to black, POL-, with K- yellow granules. Hymenium and hypothecium hyaline. Exciple hyaline inner part and pigmented dark brown outer edge, lacking algae, K-. Paraphyses appeared straight and unbranched with a dark apical cap, conglutinated.

Asci narrowly clavate, K/I+blue tholus and outer wall. Pycnidia present, conidia filiform, curved, about 20Âµm x 0.5Âµm. Spores 8/ascus. Hyaline, simple, ellipsoid. Average 15.9×5.5 (n=7).

results.notes:
Two small and thin-stiped fruiting bodies growing inside a row of planted P. abies. Bluing of the pores, stipe surface, and context was observed. The spores are smooth and not truncate, as visualized at x400 without a mounting medium (more precise measurements TBD).
I am certain obs 149448 from 5 years ago fruited only 10-15 yards from present collection, albeit it grew in the grass strip between the road and the spruce row and had a much more robust stature than this collection. Nonetheless, I surmise they are the same taxon. If the spores turn out to be smooth at x1000, which I expect them to be, then it’s not X. intermedius.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 29-Apr-21; edited 26-May-22):
> A clean and contiguous nrDNA sequence of 781 base pairs (bps) was obtained from this collection by Dr. Kudzma and uploaded by me to this observation. The sequence was assembled from two forward and two reverse reads. The full-length nrITS locus is 677 nucleotides long in this organism (ITS1 = 213 bps, 5.8S = 161 bps, ITS2 = 303 bps). The ITS spacer is preceded by the last 46 characters of nrSSU and followed by the first 58 bps of nrLSU. There are no ambiguities present, but there is a single point of heterogeneity originating from a poly-G homopolymer at the very end of the ITS2 sublocus. The shorter haplotype (GGG) is reported.
> A BLASTn of the full-length ITS sequence gave the same profile as the ITS sequences of obs 327591 (MW882069) and obs 327629 (MW882070) discussed a day ago. The 13 top hits having pairwise similarity of 98.0-99.7%, with 88-100% query cover. The top-scoring hit is associated with J.L. Frank’s voucher collected in Manhattan.1 Interestingly, both MW882069 & MW882070 from upstate NY are 98.2% similar. Accessions with identification to species (6) are labeled as ‘Boletus/Xerocomellus chrysenteron’ or ‘cf./aff. chrysenteron’ and ‘Boletellus chrysenteroides’. I called mine ‘Xerocomellus cf. intermedius’, knowing for sure that this critter cannot be the European X. chrysenteron.
Alignment of the ITS1 and ITS2 sequences in MUSCLE, shown in Fig. 1 & Fig. 2, respectively, suggests that we’re likely dealing with the same phylogenetic entity endemic to North America (NA) and showing, as expected, intraspecific variability in the ITS spacer consisting of a combination of isolated and scattered ambiguities, single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) events and gaps due to variable-length homopolymeric repeats; a few mismatches near either terminus can probably be attributed to poor read quality and possible editing errors. Ten vouchers originated from eastern NA, one was from Mexico, one from Canada and one was blank on geographic information.
> “Xerocomellus (Boletaceae) in western North America” by Frank et al. (2020) is the first major scientific publication sorting out this genus in the New World through the prism of DNA.2 The maximum likelyhood (ML) ITS tree in the paper includes only two species from eastern NA — one of them is Xerocomellus truncatus and the other is the present cryptic species (featuring the same GenBank accessions as those obtained from the BLASTn of MO327629); the authors label it as ‘Xerocomellus “chrysenteron” eNA’. The closes genetic relatives are Xerocomellus diffractus from western NA and Xerocomellus cisalpinis from Europe. The three form a statistically well-supported group (93/77). Fig. 3 reproduces the phylogenetic relationship between these three species in a ML ITS tree built from BLASTn hits in www.phylogeny.fr. (“one click” method; G-blocks are off). However, the topology of ‘Xerocomellus “chrysenteron” eNA’ looks rather busy for this to be a single species.
Sequencing of single-copy genes from additional collections and analyses of data are required to corroborate, or disprove, a single-species theory.
> Frank et al. state that “It appears that Xerocomellus species richness is greater in western North America than in eastern North America, and no Xerocomellus species are presently known to occur across the entire North American continent”. While, it’s indeed going to be difficult, if not impossible, to match, let alone exceed, the diversity of western NA Xerocomellus in the East, the “right half” of the country probably has more than just 2-3 species/OTUs known to exist.
Reference:
1 https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/67147676
2 Free access at https://www.researchgate.net/...

results.notes:
A very late fruiting of three sporocarps growing in mixed deciduous woods of beech, tulip poplar and oak (all three tree species were in the immediate vicinity, but beech is the mostly likely host), no conifers. Two other bolete species were also discovered nearby and will be posted to MO shortly. I’ve never seen these boletes previously growing at this location.
The largest cap (a post mature specimen, not collected) was 6-7" wide. The second largest fb had the following dimensions:
Overall height = 14 cm
Cap = 8.5 cm wide, convex/umbrella-shaped; 2 cm thick above the stipe
Tube layer = 1.4 cm deep
Stipe = 12 cm long, 1.9 cm wide at apex, 1.6 cm wide at narrowest point (in the middle), 2.2 cm wide at the base
The overall morphology can be inferred from the photos. Nobilis is a good possibility, but these also fit the gestalt of gertudiae (e.g., the cap color and development of the yellow band in the stipe apex). More reason to suspect the two taxa are likely conspecific.

results.notes:
A very late fruiting of a single robust sporocarp. Growing next to obs 339034 in mixed deciduous woods of beech, tulip poplar and oak (all three tree species were in the immediate vicinity, but beech is the mostly likely host), no conifers. I have found this species in this general area earlier in the year (e.g., obs 328148 and obs 332061), but this collection was on the other side of the woods across a stream running on the bottom of a 15-20 ft deep ravine.
The general morphology can be inferred from the photos. Overall height = 9.5 cm. The cap is 9 cm wide and 2.5 cm thick above the stipe. The tube layer is 5-7 mm wide. The stipe is 7 cm long, 2.2 cm wide at the flaring apex, 1.8 cm wide at the narrowest point, and 2 cm wide at the base. The cap flesh is pale yellow, bluing instantly. The stipe flesh is concolorous with the cap in the upper 1/4, and increasingly bright lemon yellow below, bluing instantly in the upper 2/3 only. The bluing eventually subsides and changes over to reddish-brown, consistent with the species concept. The odor is fungoid, with a sour and fishy note. KOH = rusty orange-brown on the pellicle, light pinkish-orange on cap context; NH4OH = pale blue flash on contact with cap pellicle, resolving rusty orange-brown, pale pinkish-orange on cap context.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted on 16-Jul-22):
This collection was sampled for ITS and TEF-1 loci by Dr. Kudzma upon my request. The TEF-1 data hasn’t been processed yet, so the discussion will focus on the spacer.
The ITS marker in this organism is quite a mess due to the presence of at least three and as many as four haplotypes, manifested by 4 (!) distinct points of heterogeneity — one in early ITS1 region and the rest in the ITS2 region – stemming from variable-length homopolymers. This is, perhaps, the most complicated case of heterogeneity I successfully dealt with through the combination of a careful and patient manual resolution of haplotypes in the raw reads and subsequent modeling of sequence overlays to explain the peak patterns observed the chromatograms.
It’s very curious that all the haplotypes are of the same length because the ITS locus starts off as a single set of peaks and also ends as a single set of peaks, as seen in the forward read. However, their internal compositions varies as single bases are inserted and deleted in a unique fashion at the four indicated locations. The haplotype ratio is inferred from the approximate area under the curve and that’s how the sequence variants can be traced.
Herein, I report only two main haplotypes, Hap-1 & Hap-2, because they stand out and their identity, IMO, is well-supported. The presence the third ITS variant is inferred from the region between the two internal points of heterogeneity separated by only 42 bases within the ITS2 sublocus (it perfectly blends in with the other two variants everywhere else in the reads and becomes “invisible”). This brief sequence segment consists of a triple peaks at each position. It is not possible to establish the exact origin of this variant with certainty – not even from the peak ratios – without doing bacterial cloning or sequencing with NexGen methodology, as it can be the derivative of either or even both reported haplotypes (in case there are 4 variants). Fig. 1 shows MUSCLE alignment of the three full-length ITS haplotypes and the differences between them. Hap-3 is the presumed sneaky minor component not submitted to GenBank. Removal of the gaps will reproduce the actual peak pattern seen in the chromatograms and will not change their overall length, which, as already stated above, is the same for all ITS variants.

Colored as the pores except white at the base, smooth and dry, flesh white.

results.notes:
Stem and underside bright medium yellow at collection, darkened to color shown. Stump was either pine or fir. Brown fibrils on stipe, cortina-like. No staining, except possibly turning bright yellow in places.
Taste bitter, slightly acrid. Cap width about 10 cm at broadest point.
The base was enlarged slightly when attached to the tree.
It would appear that the stipe is too fibrillose for the luteofolius and thiersii groups. Perhaps there had been a partial veil that is mostly gone?

From the SVIMS key, I get cap not small> no blue/green
If I consider this to have no veil, then >on wood= echinulisporus or liquiritiae group. This is not in the liquiritiae group, and the one observation of echinulisporus on this site fits this poorly.

Possibly the same as 3284

results.notes: In mixed oak, hemlock, white pine stand. Caps 7-8 cm, greenish yellow with brown fibers, especially dark at the pointed disk. Flesh thin, white. Gills white, adnate, close. Stipe 7-8 cm long x 10-12 mm thick, white. Spores hyaline in KOH, broadly ellipsoid, 5.9-6.9 × 4-5, n=30.

results.notes: In mixed oak, hemlock, white pine stand. Caps 9-14 cm, pinkish cream ground color with brown fibers and dark brown scales in the center. Flesh thick, white. Gills creamy white, close, adnate to notched, to 1 cm deep, bruising gray. Stipe to 8 cm long x 2-3 cm thick, white above annulus, brown below. White annulus about halfway down. Spores hyaline in KOH, broadly ellipsoid, 5.4-6.6 × 3.8-4.8.

results.notes: Growing from rotting birch log. Caps brownish orange over the center, lighter around the edge. Gills buff to pale gray, close, attached, with a delicate white partial veil when young. Stipes caespitose, cream at the apex, darkening to the same color as the cap, fibrillose towards the base., 7-9 cm long x 5-7 mm thick. Spores ellipsoid, yellow in KOH, 5.6-6.4 × 3.1-4. A few scattered pleurochrysocystidia, mucronate to ventricose-rostrate. Cheilocystidia abundant, broadly to short subtibiiform. Clamps present in gill trama.
